title: Identify UML Class Diagram Components
question: Create an interactive diagram game where students identify components in a UML class diagram: classes, attributes, methods, associations, inheritance arrows, composition diamonds, and multiplicity notations.

blueprint.title: UML Blueprint Decoder
blueprint.subject: Software Engineering
blueprint.narrativeIntro: Welcome, aspiring software architect! Your task is to meticulously analyze a complex UML class diagram, identifying its core components. Precision is key to building robust software systems. Let's begin by dissecting this blueprint.
blueprint.completionMessage: Excellent work, architect! You've successfully identified and understood the fundamental building blocks of a UML class diagram, a crucial skill for any software designer.

diagram.assetPrompt: A detailed UML class diagram featuring multiple interconnected classes. Each class should clearly display attributes and methods. Various types of relationships must be present, including a clear inheritance relationship (generalization), a composition relationship (strong aggregation), and at least one association with explicit multiplicity notations (e.g., 1..*, 0..1). The diagram should be complex enough to offer distinct, identifiable zones for each specified component type.

zones.label: Class
zones.description: Represents a blueprint for objects, defining their common structure (attributes) and behavior (methods). It encapsulates data and operations that instances of the class will possess.

zones.label: Attribute
zones.description: A named property or characteristic of a class, representing a piece of data that instances of the class will hold. It defines the state of an object.

zones.label: Method
zones.description: A named operation or function that a class can perform, defining the behavior or actions that instances of the class can execute.

zones.label: Association
zones.description: Indicates a structural relationship between two classes, showing that instances of one class are connected to instances of another and can interact.

zones.label: Inheritance Arrow
zones.description: Represents a generalization-specialization relationship where one class (subclass) inherits attributes and methods from another class (superclass), signifying an 'is-a' relationship.

zones.label: Composition Diamond
zones.description: Denotes a strong 'part-of' relationship where the component class cannot exist independently of the composite class, implying exclusive ownership and lifecycle dependency.

zones.label: Multiplicity Notation
zones.description: Specifies the number of instances of one class that can be associated with instances of another class in a relationship, defining the cardinality.

config.instruction_text: First, carefully examine the UML class diagram. Drag and drop each label onto the corresponding highlighted component to identify it correctly.

feedback.on_correct: Excellent! That label is correctly placed.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Take another look at the diagram and consider the function of that component. Which label best describes it?
feedback.on_completion: Fantastic job! You've successfully identified all the key components of the UML class diagram.

misconceptions.message: Remember, attributes represent the data or state of an object, while methods represent the behaviors or actions an object can perform.

UML uses different line styles, arrowheads, and adornments (like diamonds for aggregation/composition) to denote distinct semantic relationships such as association, inheritance, aggregation, and composition. Pay close attention to these visual cues!
While inheritance facilitates code reuse, its primary purpose in design is to model 'is-a' relationships, representing specialization and generalization between classes.

config.instruction_text: Now that you've labeled the components, match each description to its correct UML element on the diagram. This will confirm your understanding of their functional roles.

feedback.on_correct: Spot on! That description perfectly matches the component.
feedback.on_incorrect: Not quite. Re-read the description and think about which UML component it best defines. What specific role does that component play?
feedback.on_completion: Outstanding work! You've accurately matched all the descriptions to their respective UML class diagram components.

misconceptions.message: Attributes represent the data or state of an object, while methods represent the behaviors or actions an object can perform. Ensure your description matches the correct concept.

Different UML relationship types (association, inheritance, aggregation, composition) have distinct meanings and visual representations. Make sure the description aligns with the specific relationship's semantics.
Inheritance models 'is-a' relationships, showing specialization. While it enables code reuse, its core design purpose is structural generalization. Does your description reflect this?

descriptions.zone_class: Represents a blueprint for objects, defining their common structure (attributes) and behavior (methods). It encapsulates data and operations that instances of the class will possess.
descriptions.zone_attribute: A named property or characteristic of a class, representing a piece of data that instances of the class will hold. It defines the state of an object.
descriptions.zone_method: A named operation or function that a class can perform, defining the behavior or actions that instances of the class can execute.
descriptions.zone_association: Indicates a structural relationship between two classes, showing that instances of one class are connected to instances of another and can interact.
descriptions.zone_inheritance_arrow: Represents a generalization-specialization relationship where one class (subclass) inherits attributes and methods from another class (superclass), signifying an 'is-a' relationship.
descriptions.zone_composition_diamond: Denotes a strong 'part-of' relationship where the component class cannot exist independently of the composite class, implying exclusive ownership and lifecycle dependency.
descriptions.zone_multiplicity_notation: Specifies the number of instances of one class that can be associated with instances of another class in a relationship, defining the cardinality.

distractor_descriptions: Represents an abstract concept that cannot be instantiated directly, serving as a template for other classes.

temporalConstraints.description: Zone zone_attribute visible after zone_class is labeled
Zone zone_method visible after zone_class is labeled
